repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - State of Bahia Water Resources
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Water Resources Management Project
            in Bahia, Brazil has a satisfactory outcome, with likely
            sustainability, substantial institutional development impact
            and satisfactory performances by both the Bank and the
            Borrower. Key lessons learned include: Reforms take
            considerable time and effort to build consensus and
            political support.  In dam construction the site selection
            should be based on multiple evaluation criteria and diverse
            water uses to maximize benefits while minimizing risks. An
            integrated approach to rural development in a water scarce
            semi-arid region should center on improving the availability
            of reliable water resource for the different users. The
            demand for water is beyond social and economic needs and a
            project has to cater to satisfy multiple demands. In
            addition, the overall demand for water needs to take into
            account for ecological demand to satisfy the environmental
            needs. Resettlement can be an effective instrument for
            poverty alleviation if it is participatory and the support
            is comprehensive. The existence of pilot to demonstrate to
            the potential settlers is an important ingredient to garner
            the confidence of settlers and for them to make an informed
            decision.  Contracting or outsourcing some activities is
            cost-effective and efficient, reducing the public sectors
            burden and allowing the Government to focus on its normative
            roles.  Successful piloting creates its own incentive to
            replicate the experience in other places.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - State of Bahia Water Resources
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objectives of the Water
            Resources Management Project in the State of Bahia are: a)
            provide reliable and sustainable access to water for
            potable, municipal, industrial, and irrigation uses in
            priority river basins, primarily in areas with high
            concentration of poor rural households; b) promote
            participatory management and rational use of water
            resources, focusing on three priority river basins,
            Itapicuru, Jacare-Verde and Alto Paraguacu; c) develop
            sustainable administration, operation and management systems
            for rural water supply and irrigation infrastructure; and d)
            develop an institutional model/prototype for all the river
            basins within Bahia, with concepts which could be applicable
            to other states. The project has two components: 1) water
            resources management, to provide the necessary technical and
            financial resources to strengthen the State of Bahia's
            basins and user level institutions to effectively manage
            water resources; and 2) infrastructure investments, to
            finance the construction and rehabilitation of water
            resources storage and distribution infrastructure in the
            Itapicuru River Basin.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Bahia Water Resources Management
            Project - environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment of
            the Water Resources Management Project for Bahia, Brazil,
            which, focusing on three priority river basins, establishes
            the regulatory and institutional frameworks to form and
            implement efficient and sustainable water resources
            management policies and plans; and finances the building and
            repair of water storage and distribution infrastructure.
            Negative environmental impacts caused by the Ponto Novo
            reservoir include submersing the mata ciliar (a protective
            vegetation that helps maintain the stability of the
            riverbanks); altering water quality; changing the vegetative
            cover; damaging the vegetation on the reservoir's
            perimeter; accelerating erosion; and modifying the behavior
            of aquatic organisms. The mitigative measures are to form a
            technical commission for environmental management and a
            vegetative growth clearing plan for the flooded area;
            collect fruits/seeds from the flooded area; protect areas
            with deposits of building materials and wastes; provide
            adequate disposal of petroleum wastes and control dust;
            educate construction workers about the environment; devise a
            water quality recovery plan; rebuild and relocate roads and
            electrical lines; control activities and transit around the
            reservoir and river bank; and measure the impact on
            indigenous species while stocking the reservoir with fish. A
            resettlement plan assists in restoring or improving living
            conditions for the displaced population, and offers them
            compensation options.
